title: 109_hr883
content: The "Rural Housing Tax Credit Act of 2005" is introduced, providing a credit for first-time rural homebuyers purchasing principal residences. This Act is cited as the "Rural Housing Tax Credit Act of 2005" and adds a new section to the Internal Revenue Code for this purpose. The "Rural Housing Tax Credit Act of 2005" offers a tax credit to first-time homebuyers in rural areas for purchasing a principal residence. The credit is either 10% of the residence's purchase price or $5,000, whichever is less, with limitations based on adjusted gross income. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is limited based on adjusted gross income, with a maximum credit of $30,000 ($60,000 for joint returns). Modified adjusted gross income includes any excluded amounts from gross income. The credit cannot exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is limited based on adjusted gross income. For married individuals filing jointly, the credit is allowable if the residence is qualified for both spouses. For married individuals filing separately, the credit amount is reduced to $2,500. The tax credit for first-time homebuyers in rural areas is allocated among unmarried individuals purchasing a qualified residence, with a maximum credit of $5,000. Definitions for terms like "rural area," "first-time homebuyer," and "principal residence" are provided in the legislation. The terms 'purchase' and 'purchase price' are defined as per section 1400C(e). Any excess credit in a taxable year can be carried forward to the next year. Reporting requirements may be necessary for verifying taxpayer eligibility for the credit. Recapture of the credit may occur in certain sales situations. If taxpayer fails to use or sells qualified residence within 5 years of purchase with credit, tax increases by credit recapture amount, which is a percentage of the credit allowed. The tax credit recapture amount is determined based on a percentage of the credit allowed if the taxpayer fails to use or sells the qualified residence within 5 years of purchase. Interest is also charged on the overpayment amount for each prior taxable year. The tax credit recapture percentage decreases over 5 years if the qualified residence is sold. Year 1 has a 100% recapture rate, decreasing to 0% after Year 5. The tax credit recapture percentage decreases over 5 years if the qualified residence is sold, with a 100% recapture rate in Year 1 decreasing to 0% after Year 5. Any increase in tax under this subsection is not considered for determining tax credits or for section 55 purposes. Certain exceptions apply to the disposition of a qualified residence due to death, casualty loss, or involuntary conversion. The tax credit recapture percentage decreases over 5 years if the qualified residence is sold, with a 100% recapture rate in Year 1 decreasing to 0% after Year 5. Exceptions apply to disposition due to death, casualty loss, or involuntary conversion. Section 1016 of the tax code is amended for basis adjustments related to the purchase of a residence. The tax code is amended to include new provisions related to tax credits for residences, specifically referencing section 25C. Various sections of the tax code are amended to incorporate section 25C, including sections 23, 24, 25, and 26. The tax code is amended to include section 25C for tax credits on residences, with various sections like 23, 24, 25, and 26 being updated accordingly. Section 904(i) and 1400C(d) are amended to include section 25C. Section 25C provides tax credits for first-time rural homebuyers. The effective dates for the amendments are specified, with different timelines for purchases and taxable years. Section 25C of the tax code provides credits for first-time rural homebuyers, with specific effective dates for amendments. The amendments include provisions regarding the amount of tax, carryovers of credit, and the stacking of sections within the code.
